review_title: The cons have won for now
pros: Excellent pay, great benefits and PTO, meaningful work, wonderful coworkers
cons: Upper management has begun to "crackdown" on minor offenses since wage increases were implemented (as we are viewed as dispensible now) and finds minor discrepancies (often invented) to fire and/or punish employees despite union presence. They punish outspoken employees on a regular basis. Also total lack of transparency in policy creation and upper management operation.

pros: Pay, peers, helping, pto, benefits
cons: No cons really if I didn't move I would have stayed

pros: If you are interested in a career in the mental health field, you will learn more in 6 months as a residential counselor at DESC than you would in 2 years of college. The hourly pay is decent, and the medical and paid time off benefits are amazing.
cons: There can be frightening situations when a person is under the influence of substances and/or having a mental health crisis, and sometimes there are not enough staff there to feel safe.

review_title: Great mission, lack of direction from leadership sometimes
job_title: Emergency Shelter Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: Union, pays decent, helping the community, culture (while not for everyone) inviting and friendly
cons: Lack of direction from leadership and bizarre decision-making sometimes. Not for the faint of heart, clients will test your patience daily.

pros: They provide a lot of time off
cons: They have a tendency to treat employees poorly, and have inexperienced managers

pros: Great benefits Great Employees and Management
cons: Not Enough Training for Employees

review_title: Great coworkers and fulfilling work, inept and intrusive leadership that bites more than it can chew
job_title: Clinical Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros:
You work with amazing individuals - some of the most dedicated and caring people you'll ever meet. You get to work closely with clients providing comprehensive care - no week is the same and you'll constantly be learning. Many direct supervisors across programs are supportive and have your back.

Great PTO system - more than most employees ever have a chance to utilize - and fully covered Kaiser PPO with a very low deductible and max annual cost for individual.

Self-professed Housing First and Harm Reduction philosophy that align with the best practices of public health.

Represented by SEIU 1199NW and some of our most passionate frontline workers.
cons:
Management regularly makes unpopular top-down decisions that harm employee retention, workload, and client care, and is stubbornly unresponsive to feedback.

Organization is growing faster than it can staff and/or train, regularly taking on new contracts with the county and city that open new positions poaching from deeply understaffed existing programs. While more permanent supportive housing and crisis response services is desperately needed in Seattle, DESC's senior leadership is unable to effectively create these new programs without taking away from existing services. Roughly 30% of positions are empty at any given time. The most well respected and client-centered senior leaders have resigned citing this kind of concern. 

Management perennially creates more and more $80k+ middle management positions to promote itself into, creating more and more layers between the front line and executive director that are filled by external hires who don't have any understanding of the work or clients. 

The system is crumbling and it's failing clients in every area of care. This isn't the fault of DESC management, but it's painful to be witness and part of. 

Pay is unlivable - management has stalled on promised negotiations for over a year. Many make just $19/hr doing the hardest, most client crisis-centered jobs at the agency. Case managers are at $46k, while other agencies in Pioneer Square have starting wages of $72k despite being funded with the same public contracts. KCRHA has made a point of how poorly we're paid.

As a result, very high turnover. It seems like 2/3rds of new hires last less than 6 months.

pros: Your fellow Frontline staff will be the kindest, most amazing people you'll ever meet.
cons: Dangerous work environment, abusive management, unliveable wages, very little opportunity for growth. Avoid at all costs for your physical and mental safety. You are better off working at a bakery or some sort of pizza place. Do not work here if you care about your own sanity and well-being.

pros: Great values, good people, plenty of training and support. Some of the best benefits I've ever had. Highly recommend this organization.
cons: Hiring process is thorough and lengthy..

review_title: Amazing clients, tough work and environement
job_title: Mental Health Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: DESC is doing incredible work for the homeless community in Seattle!
cons: There are serious issues with what DESC expects of employees but the union is pretty strong.

job_title: Client Engagement Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros:
Passionate coworkers
Interesting clients
Lots of room to grow
Internal promotions are very common
Good benefits and employee protections, especially for union positions
cons:
Emotionally tiring
Managers and directors can be hard to reach
Some positions are very high-stress
Must have good personal boundaries to maintain work-life balance

pros: loved working here may get burned out but the team environment makes it worth it.
cons: burn out and pay was not the best

job_title: Clinical Support Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: This work is crucial and very hard and DESC steps up to do the work that needs to be done. They truly are a housing first model and go to great lengths to help clients. They offer very generous PTO, or at least they used to.
cons: It's dangerous work. Let me be clear, people experiencing a mental health conditions are not any more dangerous/violent than the general population (statistically), but having so many people that are in crisis/experiencing psychosis/using drugs and alcohol means that there are some scary events. You are expected to put up with a lot of verbal abuse (and in some cases physical abuse). The people with the most difficult jobs on the front lines (Residential Counselors) tend to have the least training/education. It's just really, really hard work.

pros:
Hands on
Plenty of room for growth 
Wide range of location 
Direct contact with guest/clients
Flexibility
cons:
Little to no support. 
Majority of time is short staff
Mentally drainage 
Low wages
Safety concerns not taken seriously

review_title: DESC management does not invest in existing programs
pros:
Amazing opportunities to connect with and serve some of the most vulnerable populations in Seattle.

Many advancement opportunities in different programs
cons:
Management fails to support supervisors, frontline staff, and ultimately clients.

Work is rewarding, but unsustainable. DESC invests next to nothing in their teams and writes-off high turnover as unavoidable rather than address systemic issues that employees call out. 

Clients are placed in unsafe conditions.

job_title: Emergency Services Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: Flexible, helping the homeless community
cons: It can be a troubled population to work with sometimes

pros: Always opportunities to advance to different positions in different programs
cons: It can be emotionally draining if you stay in one program for too long

pros: I guess there's a decent amount of PTO, 6 weeks, but they're closed federal holidays and you need to to use your own PTO for those clsures.
cons: They are very corporate and "profit" is the primary concern. The board of directors is half cops and half property management and Architects with not a single social worker (some may count police officers as social workers, so maybe read that as no trained social workers) on the board.

pros: Highly diverse and inclusive workforce.
cons: nothing that comes to mind.

pros: great work place easy going and good pay
cons: Lots of hours but its ok

job_title: Clinical Support Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: great benefits and pto accrual
cons: plagued by red tape just like any other agency.

pros: The work they do for the community is imperative and they get a lot of negative publicity.
cons: Not enough personnel for the work that needs to get done. Not a lot of training.

review_title: Be kind to yourself and avoid DESC
pros: Harm reduction and housing first values. Clinical staff use client centered methods. Some entry level positions are decent for people who need social services experience.
cons: There are no caps for clinical caseloads. Staff at every level of the organization are treated as disposable. It operates an internal propaganda machine that sends a message to burnt out staff that they're weak, have bad boundaries or bad self-care. There is an unnecessary layer of demoralization.

pros: Good job, coworkers are great, PTO is good
cons: It's hard to get clients into housing

pros: - the people you help
cons: Some departments need to be looked at closely by management with how program managers and coworkers who have stayed there for long time treat new staff members

review_title: Do great work and gain experience in social services
pros: Culture, mission, great health insurance, lots of paid time off, recent pay bumps
cons: Lots of variety between programs/projects, some are dysfunctional and unorganized.

job_title: Social Worker/Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Experience is good, if you're willing to learn and put up with the downsides.
cons: Downsides, low pay, bad benefits, a lot of people who don't care.

pros: Rewarding work with the clients
cons: difficult job, union not helpful

job_title: Clinical Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Great co-workers and supervisors that do care about our needs and help as much as they can.
cons: Upper management doesn't seem to care too much. High turn over rates currently due to extensive covid burnout

pros: Some good people, Amazing population, Loved the work
cons: Bullying, yelling, harassment, very little job training.

job_title: Behavioral Health Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Good outer appearance of supposedly caring about the workers
cons: The whole approach is flawed. No one stays more than a year and nothing is effectively done about the homelessness crisis.

pros: The majority of DESC staff really care about their work, the clients, and coworkers. I looked forward to working nearly every day.
cons: Low expectations held for on-call workers

pros: Experience with vulnerable populations, including those experiencing homelessness and those with chronic SI, SUD, and serious mental illness.
cons:
Inadequate training and compensation
Safety concerns

pros: Important work, good people, harm reduction focus
cons: Hard work, low pay, high turnover

pros: Many interaction with departments and clients keeps the job interesting.
cons: Often more work to do than humanly possible without putting in a lot of overtime.

pros: great coworkers and mission driven
cons: backstabbing, underpaid, underappreciated, dangerous, cliques

job_title: Community Support Worker in Vernon, BC
pros: good benefits , pay middle of the road
cons: not the best management personal

review_title: Great place to learn social work.
pros: Good people working alongside you.
cons: Pay is very low, but that is the case for most social work jobs.

pros: Great coworkers for the most part and looks great on resume. Great experience for future career goals

job_title: CERTIFIED PEER SPECIALIST in Seattle, WA
pros: Diversity, good paid time off, and population of people we serve
cons: it is very under staffed

pros: Working with and for good people

job_title: Clinical Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Good mission and values, great people and clients
cons: Lack of transparency from upper management

pros: The people, the goals, the mission
cons: The amount of work far exceeds the resources available

job_title: Mental Health Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: generous PTO, great benefits, emphasis on self-care
cons: high caseloads; managed care means meeting service minute requirements; management is becoming more and more money-driven; inexperienced supervision; lack of professionalism

review_title: Good work with a good team
pros: Benefits are awesome. Very good team to work with
cons: pay is below industry standard for this area

pros: Mission to serve most vulnerable clients
cons:
Poor upper management
Benefits not as good as advertised

pros: The job itself is wonderful. It’s really hard but the clients are great. Even when they are being difficult. It’s a profound experience to do this work and rewarding unto itself.
cons:
Upper and middle management employs antiquated autocratic opinions that were proven to kill morale and motivation as early as 1937.
There is a derisive attitude towards “boots on the ground”. 

This results in a pervasive Groupthink and the resultant extremely poor choices for Program Managers.
The result is a toxic work environment on top of work that can be stressful on its own merits.

There are PMs who use administrative grievances to attack and harass some employees in a bully like manner. This behaviour is encouraged at the top. It’s a “keep them in their place “,  attitude.

The tragic mindset of management ruins what would otherwise be wonderful work.

pros: Opportunities for OT, reasonable pay, ~30 days PTO a year, lots of different properties to work at, harm reduction, non-religious, good health insurance, they hire people from all walks of life, they believe in second chances when they want to, they're going through a lot of changes now, so the right person in the right position could have a big impact. Accommodations for school.
cons: Budget cuts, lack of transparency, no on-the-job training to orient to the job, teams lack communication. Management is inconsistent, striving to uphold the DESC vision, yet each having their own ideas of what that is exactly. Staff can and are verbally and physically assaulted by clients and the situations are rarely discussed seriously with the clients. Harm reduction turns quickly to enabling with the residents as the clinical staff typically see mental health and substance use as a crippling impairment and not something that can be managed successfully. Upward mobility is reserved for people in the click. Intelligence is punished, laziness rewarded. Questioning management makes you a target. Little upward mobility for minorities. High turnover.

review_title: Solid place to break into social work
pros: Clients are difficult but amazing, great place to learn about social work and expose yourself to truly all different ways of doing this work (people are in vastly different places in terms of mental illness, addiction and recovery), allows for a lot of freedom in how work is done with clients including a lot of outreach if desired, frequently do activities with clients in the community, great vacation benefits, agency generally prioritizes clients' needs over all others
cons: Low pay, lots of paperwork (which can limit free time to do work with clients if you're bad at managing it), recent shift in management that seems to prioritize management needs vs employees, work can be difficult and exhausting--you really need to manage trauma stewardship/secondary trauma, doesn't tend to generally offer vast opportunities in terms of employee growth (i.e. supervision hours for licensure, training budgets, higher-level trainings, flexibility around educational needs)

pros: Working with the clients is fulfilling and interesting, and the agency's philosophical approach to serving vulnerable populations is going in the right direction. If you get into a good program with a good supervisor and staff, you can learn a lot, and there's a lot of room to develop your own style of practice. DESC can provide you with invaluable work experience when it comes to serving people with who have histories of homelessness and co-occurring disorders.
cons: Upper management appears to have formed its own inner circle and does not care about input from employees who actually work with the agency's clients. Consequently, upper management is detached from both their clients and their employees. Salary and benefits are low relative to the amazing work that staff do. High turnover rates result, making work even more difficult for staff who does remain. Employees are also provided with negligible training to deal with exceptionally difficult clients and working conditions, meaning you learn as you go, for better and worse.

pros: The clients are great, once you take the time to get to know them as individuals. You feel like you're actually doing something for these people.
cons: It's a tough job. It's really hard, and often time it's grunt work. You see some pretty awful stuff, and it's emotional. You have to be strong to get up and go to work everyday.

review_title: Great mission, hard work and poor staffing
job_title: Clinical Support Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros:
The clients are a very high needs and vulnerable population and you can make a huge difference in their lives by providing basic needs - shelter/housing/clothing/food/etc

The agency's mission is inspiring and they are committed to developing best practices and evidence in the field of housing first and harm reduction.
cons:
Expanding and not being able to retain staff due to low wages and stressful work. 

Sometimes feels like just maintaining clients' status quo with no quality and effective clinical intervention - not enough actual therapy for my clients, just case management.

Leadership and management is really mixed quality. some supervisors are great, others are ineffective.

Some cliques and factions amongst staff, lots of staff that have been there for a long time and think they know everything (they don't).

review_title: It's a good place to get ones foot in the proverbial door, but buyer beware!
pros: Desc offers generous paid time off, and the work schedules are consistent. If you are new to  the field, you can gain experience and exposure to working with a vulnerable population of adults who are homeless and experience severe and persistent mental health and substance abuse issues.
cons:
The pay is so low that my coworkers and I often compared notes on where there are food and other community resources that we were able to utilize so that we could encourage ends to meet. 
Due to this low pay, some employees don't work as hard as they could, leaving those with a half way decent work ethic to pick up the slack. Most new employees left within the first couple of months of hire.
Bedbugs! They are everywhere, and they don't discuss it in the interview. Had they mentioned exposure to bedbugs, I would not have accepted the offer.

job_title: Peer Specialist in West Seattle, WA
pros: The only reason why I gave DESC two stars instead of one star is because its a great place to get your foot in the door to start a career in the mental health field and the Paid Time Off (PTO) is AWESOME.
cons: The great staff, including supervisors don't stay long because its a foot in the door agency. You top out salary wise at the end of five years. If you don't want a revolving door then pay more. I understand that its "all about funding resources" but topping out only after five years just sucks.

job_title: Clinical Support Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: The number one pro is the clients that DESC choose to serve. Working at DESC, I had so many wonderful co-workers. So many staff really care and bend over backwards for their clients. DESC provides a lot of valuable trainings and educational opportunities. It is a great place to learn a lot. I felt very valued by my team and supervisors. I really loved the framework and approach to services.  The PTO is great.  Overall I really loved my experience at DESC and would work there again.
cons: The pay. The fact that they do not provide you with a ORCA pass.

review_title: Low salary, few opportunities for growth
job_title: Clinical Support Specialist and Residential Counselor
pros: Relaxed management style, flex hours with this position, a lot of PTO
cons: Ill-defined job description, low salary, little development from management and few opportunities for growth, often feel like I'm expected by management to be more like a landlord or parent than a counselor, inconsistent treatment of clients by staff due to inconsistent expectations set by lack of training (some fellow staff can be rude), even housed clients live in pretty dismal environments, you're exposed to bedbugs (I've brought one home from work).

review_title: HR dept makes me want to BANG HEAD AGAINST WALL.
job_title: Clinical Support Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros:
Overall I'm VERY proud to have worked at DESC. It's not a perfect organization but it serves the most vulnerable and marginalized members of the community, has a widespread positive impact, and is the LEADER in the region for many reasons.

1. The clientele! Working here is challenging but extremely gratifying and the client you serve will touch your heart.
2. Represented by SEIU Union! Union reps have fought hard to earn non-managerial DESC staff better wages, better benefits, and overall protection. Because of the Union we are able to keep management accountable and uphold the values of equity, justice, and integrity. 
3. Plenty of opportunity for career development, growth, mentorship, on-going training, upward mobility on the "social work ladder." 

 I feel lucky to have ended up on a strong team where I felt supported and appreciated.
cons:
The HR department is sour. It's laughable/frustrating how all the voicemails I left went ignored when I needed them to do relatively simple job tasks. Never any follow-up unless you go knock on their door and track them down. I'm very bitter about the laziness, apathy and unprofessionalism. Why?
1. Went a couple months without medical and dental benefits (which I had earned and was eligible for) because one of them put in my SSN off by one digit to the providers. I had to fix the whole thing and jump through hoops to correct their mistake.
2. Had to hold their hand to get my W9 during tax season. Asked again and again for my W9 and was very late to get it. 
3. Didn't get any of my PTO paid out when I left. They require a FOUR WEEK notice (which is unheard of at virtually any other company.. anything over 2 weeks notice is courtesy.) I had 17 hrs left on the table when I left, which is just frustrating on principle because I gave them over 3 weeks notice, not to mention my supervisors and project manager had well over a month of informal notice that I was leaving... and in my final 3 weeks I elected to work a bunch of 9 hour days to tie up all lose ends. Employees earn that PTO and DESC needs to stop being so cheap about that. 
4. No exit interview!? Called them and left voicemails asking for some follow-up and they never had the decency to call me back. On my last day of work, I found out they misfiled documentation on my insurance, so even though I was insured for the remainder of the month, I wasn't covered for prescriptions. Premara said that this looked like a clear mistake, one easy to fix, and to contact HR so they could resolve it. But HR never returned my calls (shocking).

review_title: Upper management doesn't care, but we care about the clients.
pros: Working at DESC, I've made a lot of really great friends out of coworkers. Our direct supervisors are (mostly) amazing and supportive. But the clients are the reason we stay. They are terrible and wonderful all in one. Working at DESC gives you a new view on humanity, and an appreciation for people who you might otherwise never interact with.
cons: Upper management doesn't seem to realize the hard work we put in day to day, resulting in pay so low that between my student loans, cell phone bill and car insurance, I can't afford to live on my own. Us "lowly shelter/residential counselors" end up sick all the time, we take home bed bugs and lice, end up with MRSA and cellulitis, pneumonia and bronchitis. We are exposed to massive amounts of bodily fluids, unknown chemical substances and drugs, and we have to deal with broken glass pipes, needles and weapons found on clients. We put up with intense, hurtful verbal abuse from clients daily, and many staff members have been physically assaulted on more than one occasion. We are first responders and are frequently put in situations where our actions dictate whether a client lives or dies. It's stressful, and it can cause a lot of negative feelings in your life if you're not careful.

job_title: Clinical Support Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Passionate, hard-working people who care about the people they serve and care about doing good work. Staff are appreciated and have ability to communicate with senior management in all-staff meetings. Great time off and healthcare benefits.
cons: The pay is very low and it is difficult to live in or near the city of Seattle on this salary alone. This is a great job if your spouse has a higher paying job.

pros: Caring employees, Flexibility, Variety, Good Introduction to Social Work, Bonus Shifts +$6/hour and OT available
cons: Pay, high turnover, stress, employees not aligned with mission statement

pros:
Co-workers are dedicated to serving the clients
People are sincere in their work because it's obviously not for the pay
Generous PTO, managers are highly encourage self-care
Pay increase automatically every 6 months for the first two years
Lots of opportunities to move around within the agency
cons:
The pay is barely livable 
Being that we are funded by the the gov't we don't always get to make our own decisions. This can lead to job description changes and serving an entirely different client base 
Pay increases automatically every 6 months for the first two years
Not a lot of vertical opportunities within the agency

job_title: Mental Health Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Employer pays full health and dental insurance, extremely generous PTO (21 hrs/month), excellent retirement plan, commuter benefit, ambitious team atmosphere, dedicated supervisors, free range work allows for unlimited creativity and independence/not chained to your desk, amazing opportunities for training/career advancement, vulnerable clients present unlimited client contact and practice experience, union representation, nonprofit.
cons: No overtime and difficult to manage workload in 40 given hours, highly stressful with tricky-to-manage time commitments, challenging personalities

job_title: RN Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Great non-profit with salary and benefits such as PTO (Paid Time Off). Great work experience for burgeoning Social Workers/Case Managers.
cons: The turn-over rate for this job is high (on average people stay there for about a year and half). Working with the homeless population can be tough but if you can handle what it throws at you I would say you can handle just about anything. A great job to have on your resume.

pros:
Good introductory experience to the field of social work/working with vulnerable populations.
Excellent mental health benefits and PTO accrual (but don't expect to be able to use them at holidays).
cons: Very high stress. The entire premise of housing first means that people are openly doing drugs, drinking, and engaging in prostitution in the buildings. Violent behavior, conflict, and overdoses are common, and DESC locations are can end up calling 911 multiple times in a shift. After a year of calling the police constantly for the same people doing the same behavior with no consequence, it can become mentally taxing. Unless you're doing day shift (7:30 - 4), the hours are pretty isolating.

pros: I love working for DESC, I love working with the residents. I love the fact that I'm able to pick up extra shifts wherever needed, without the headaches of an employer haggling me about going over 40 hours. Really happy with the benefits that we have as well. The PTO makes it really nice as well.
cons: We could really use a pay increase.

review_title: No respect for entry level staff
pros:
Get to know and work with one of the toughest populations in the area
Feel a real sense of accomplishment working with homeless and getting them housing
GREAT PTO
cons:
Shoddy medical benefits
Do-nothing union
Weird office politics
Complete lack of respect for RCs

review_title: Great agency, poor admin/mgmt, great coworkers
pros: The staff is widly diverse and most genuinely care about clents.
cons: Lowest pay for similar agencies. However, this means the long-time staff are really cool and committed to the harm-reduction, housing-first models.

pros: Great colleagues, fast pace, good benefits
cons: Terrible management structure, little attention to employee safety, no support whatsoever when employees are injured or threatened by clients, bottom line is money, not clients

job_title: Mental Health Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Great mission, committed and skilled staff, can be a fun place to work, always interesting, good training ground
cons: Workload unrealistic, high stress, lots of paperwork, management seldom solicits or takes advice from workers, management is not very innovative, resources are scarce

pros: Some of the best and most rewarding experiences I have had in my life have been working with the clients here at DESC.
cons: RCs, on-calls, janitorial staff and other "lower level" employees are given NO respect.  I voiced concern about a manager to HR and they forwarded the email to that manager, forcing me to transfer to avoid conflict.  This is endemic to the management culture at DESC, and lately it feels like they view their clients as a way to make money, not people they can help.

pros: Serving vulnerable people and helping others.  Working with clients who have many struggles and assisting them with what they need.
cons: The pay sucks. No tuition reimbursement. Company hires people who hate their job, and are disrespectful to clients.

pros: Working here gives you credibility and other employers will take your skills seriously, lots of PTO, promotion from within-lots of room to grow, great place to learn about mental health, SUD, and health
cons: Do not work alone at night!  Very dangerous!  Super stressful, very low wage

pros: Helping undeserved populations (the homeless, persons with mental illness or chemical dependency)
cons: Authoritarian management, top-down feel. It is difficult to get your concerns addressed without feeling like you somehow did something wrong.

review_title: Great place to work if you want to help those in need
pros: Interaction with the vulnerable, feeling that you have made a difference in one's life, trying to give those who are vulnerable a chance to thrive.
cons: Some staff do not take their jobs seriously and do not necessarily look out for the best interest in the client.

review_title: I mean, it's a social services nonprofit.  It's what you'd expect.
job_title: Mental Health Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Coworkers who really care and are super supportive, clients who are doing their best, lots of PTO.
cons: Management is completely out of the loop when it comes to what front line staff have to deal with, and have ridiculous unrealistic expectations.

pros: Health insurance is covered 100%, paid time off is generous
cons: Staff safety is a low priority. Alone time with unstable clients is the norm, and even when a safety incident occurs (which is fairly often), they don't change a thing. Turnover is high and understaffing is the norm.

pros: Paid time off, great insurance, union, bus pass paid for
cons: You may get a threat here and there from one of the residents who are not medicating properly or finding some other issue present in their life.

review_title: Focus on employee self care but not really
pros:
Plenty of OT
Great Client Interactions
Great Work Experience
cons:
See's employee's as easily replaceable
High turnover
level of training not sufficient for work

job_title: Clinical Support Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Great benefits like PTO and Health Coverage
cons: Wages could be higher, especially for Residential Counselors and Janitors.

pros: Great team - everybody is supportive of each other.
cons: No safety,  small salary, huge case load, no support from upper management and huge staff turnover.

pros:
Great PTO.  Working with the most vulnerable people in the city.  Hard work, but great 'warm fuzzies'!  Great co-workers!!!!!
Housing First and Harm Reduction! IT WORKS!!!!!!!
cons: Hard population, but worth it.  Salary is not great, but benefits are good!

pros: Applies harm reduction and housing first framework. Amazing clients and staff.
cons: Culture of working overtime, employing on-call employees inequitable and contributes to burnout.

review_title: A great place to start a career
job_title: PSYCH REGISTERED NURSE in Seattle, WA
pros: Staff are kind, fun, and welcoming
cons: Pay is on the lower end

review_title: One of the better social service agencies
pros: effective technology, caring coworkers, supportive supervisors, great agency model, fast promotion, lots of PTO, scheduling flexibility
cons: low pay, high turnover leads to lots of inexperienced staff

pros: Clients are great to work with
cons:
Staff doesnt listen. 
Always in your business, telling in you.

pros: It is nice being in a position to help a demographic that definitely needs it. The people you work with are usually fantastic!
cons: Poor pay coupled with under appreciation by upper management. Lots of violence and other traumatic experiences.

pros: You are working with a group of society that tends to be forgotten or swept under the rug.
cons: The administrative area of this company is seriously lacking. The company will do anything not to pay their employees what they are worth.

pros: Gratifying work, great experience. Excellent coworkers and colorful clients.
cons:
Low pay!!
Turn-over. 
Stressful. It all depends on the project/team- some are easier than others and the culture depends on the project within DESC

pros: Clients are amazing! coworkers ROCK! PTO
cons: You cant trust anything managers say. That simple. The pay is the lowest ever.

pros: The clients we serve make it all worthwhile
cons: There is always more to do - its easy to burn out

job_title: On-call Residential Counselor in Seattle, WA
pros: You get some interesting work experience with a unique population
cons: low salary, not the best work environment, poor training to deal with client issues

pros: I enjoyed the people I work with, everyone was passionate about helping the homeless population of the greater Seattle area

pros: Working with residents was difficult but very rewarding. If you're good at it, you can really make a significant difference in their lives.
